intro: Acaena sanguisorbae subsp. pusilla, commonly known as the dwarf thimbleweed, is a low-growing perennial plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its small, spiny bracts and clusters of white flowers. The plant has small, alternate leaves that are typically covered in fine hairs. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important species in its native habitat.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena sanguisorbae subsp. pusilla is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the northern and central regions of the country. This subspecies typically grows in coastal and lowland areas. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in disturbed habitats. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones within New Zealand.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena sanguisorbae subsp. pusilla was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and small, spiky fruits. However, it has since become invasive, spreading rapidly in natural ecosystems. The plant thrives in disturbed soils and can outcompete native vegetation. Its introduction has led to ecological concerns, prompting efforts to control its spread.
